skill.name: Writing Hookify Rules
skill.description: This skill should be used when the user asks to "create a hookify rule", "write a hook rule", "configure hookify", "add a hookify rule", or needs guidance on hookify rule syntax and patterns.
skill.summary: This skill should be used when the user asks to "create a hookify rule", "write a hook rule", "confi...
skill.author: unknown

security_audit.summary: Official skill from an approved source. Minimal audit performed and no risks identified. Safe to publish.

content.value_statement: You need clear rules to detect risky commands or edits. This skill explains Hookify rule syntax and safe regex patterns.
actual_capabilities: Explains Hookify rule file structure with YAML frontmatter
Lists event types and required fields for rules
Shows basic and multi condition rule formats
Provides pattern writing tips and regex pitfalls
Defines naming and file location conventions
limitations: Does not generate or install rule files automatically
Assumes Hookify is already installed and configured
Does not validate regex correctness in your environment
No runtime enforcement beyond written guidance

use_cases.title: Block risky commands
use_cases.description: Create bash rules to warn or block dangerous operations like rm or chmod.

use_cases.title: Catch debug logs
use_cases.description: Detect console.log or debugger in file edits before commits.

use_cases.title: Enforce checklists
use_cases.description: Add stop event rules that remind teams to run tests and update docs.

prompt_templates.title: Basic rule
prompt_templates.prompt: Write a simple Hookify rule that warns when a bash command uses rm -rf. Include name, enabled, event, pattern, and a brief message.

prompt_templates.title: File edit check
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a file event rule that warns when new_text contains API_KEY and file_path ends with .env. Provide a clear warning message.

prompt_templates.title: Multi condition rule
prompt_templates.prompt: Draft a Hookify rule with conditions that match .ts files and detect console.log usage. Use regex_match and include guidance text.

prompt_templates.title: Process checklist
prompt_templates.prompt: Write a stop event rule that reminds the assistant to verify tests and build status before stopping.

output_examples.input: Create a Hookify rule to warn on sudo commands in bash.
output: Rule name uses a clear verb and kebab case
Event is set to bash with a regex for sudo
Message explains the risk and suggests alternatives

best_practices: Use specific regex patterns to avoid false positives
Keep messages short and actionable with clear alternatives
Store rules in .claude with descriptive file names
anti_patterns: Using overly broad patterns like log without context
Hardcoding exact command paths that rarely match
Forgetting to set enabled to true

faq.question: Is this compatible with Claude Code and Codex?
faq.answer: It targets Hookify rules for Claude Code workflows and can guide Codex users who follow the same file format.

faq.question: What are the main limits of this skill?
faq.answer: It provides guidance only and does not run regex tests or create files for you.

faq.question: How do I integrate the rules into my repo?
Does this skill handle sensitive data?
faq.answer: It only provides instructions and does not access or store your data.

faq.question: What should I do if a rule does not trigger?
faq.answer: Review the event type, field names, and regex pattern for mismatches and test with a small example.

faq.question: How does it compare to generic linting tools?
faq.answer: Hookify rules can target tool events and prompts, while linters focus on code syntax and style.
